channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Companies Commit to Making it Easier for Workers to Vote in the Election
item.description: Zoom out: This Election Day, many workers won't have to make a decision.     And if "encouragement" isn't enough, employers are legally required to give workers time off to vote in 30 states.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Netflix's 'The Queen's Gambit' is Causing a Surge in Online Chess Play
item.description: I've always wanted to bring it to the masses," says Hikaru Nakamura, a hugely popular chess streamer on Twitch and the top-ranked blitz chess player in the world.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: The Essentials, Issue #78: Care package
item.description: Leading Off    Giphy This election is giving all of us anxious energy—waking up half an hour before your alarm, over-caffeinating, and binge-eating your leftover Halloween candy.   ------  If you haven’t already, don’t forget to vote!   Happy Place    Mollie K.     Dept.   Cook your way through election week with this meal plan. of Cool Ideas All around the world: Here’s a map that shows you the true size of every country.   25 feel-good movies that are worth the rewatch.   Stay informed: When you’re sick of waking up to “I’m Michael Barbaro, a reporter at the New York Times,” try listening to What A Day—a podcast breaking down the biggest news of the day.   Stay healthy: Every time I take a trip to the grocery store, I’m overwhelmed by all the plant-based milk choices.   Stay rested: If you can’t focus at work and you find yourself plowing through a Netflix series per night, you’re most likely mentally exhausted.   Most of us will need a few tips on how to make the post-election hangover less miserable. I’ll see you on Thursday. Mollie has been living (and trapped) in the Central American country for more than 9 months now. Pop quiz: A fascinating experiment to see how we view history.
item.author: Rachel Cantor

item.title: The Historical Performance of the Stock Market Based on Presidential Party
item.description: What does that mean for stocks?   Regardless of party, the S&P performs better in a president’s first term than in the second.   Stocks have typically gained more when either party holds a simple majority in the Senate—not more than 60 of the 100 seats.   Bank of America Global Research analyzed historic S&P performance under presidents from both parties.   Investors wish they could take a long weekend in Aruba, but in 2020 there’s no such thing: Tomorrow is Election Day, which will determine what party holds power in D.C. for the next few years.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Brew Crossword: High-volume turnout
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: How TV Networks Are Preparing for Election Night 2020
item.description: Bottom line: Don’t tell these networks traditional TV is dead.   A mudslide of early votes. Some tally them as they arrive, but others don’t even start until after polls close.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Meet the Restaurant Group Buying Dunkin’
item.description: What’s Inspire Brands? The Dunkquisition will nearly triple Inspire’s store footprint, bringing both Dunkin’ Donuts and Baskin Robbins into the fold.     What Dunkin’ brings to the counter: The breakfast market, which was one of the only growing sectors in the restaurant biz before Covid-19 arrived and commutes went kaput.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: The Historical Performance of the Stock Market Based on Presidential Party
item.description: Regardless of party, the S&P performs better in a president’s first term than in the second.   What does that mean for stocks?   Stocks have typically gained more when either party holds a simple majority in the Senate—not more than 60 of the 100 seats.   BofA Global Research analyzed historic S&P performance under presidents from both parties.   Investors wish they could take a long weekend in Aruba, but in 2020 there’s no such thing: Tomorrow is Election Day, which will determine what party holds power in D.C. for the next few years.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Week Ahead: November 2
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Some Retailers Board Up Shops Ahead of Election Day
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: What's Trending This Halloween
item.description: What other Halloween trends are we watching this year?   You can see what costumes are the most popular by exploring Google's Frightgeist site. Elizabeth Holmes. Another popular fit?
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: heme Parks To Miss out on Halloween Revenue Boost This Year
item.description: Since then, Halloween has turned into a turkey-leg-at-Disney-World-sized revenue driver for the theme park industry.   And parks from Disney World to Busch Gardens report significant Q4 revenue bumps every year thanks to Halloween celebrations.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Halloween Candy Sales up 8.6%
item.description: As of Oct. 4, Halloween chocolate and candy sales were up 8.6% annually, according to the National Confectioners Association.   Zoom out: You're not alone in buying Costco packs of chocolate for yourself. It also toned down its Halloween branding to avoid discounting inventory come Nov. 1.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Halloween Pop-Up Shops Have Mixed Success In 2020
item.description: Last year, sales per store declined nearly 21% annually—a major problem for parent Party City considering Halloween sales account for a fifth of its total U.S. retail revenue. Every year, pop-up Halloween stores rise from the underworld to possess empty storefronts vacated by mortal retailers.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: How to Sell a Haunted House
item.description: So how do you sell a haunted house?   That seems to be the exception to rule, because haunted houses are typically not an easy sell. Both Lynnewood Hall (dubbed the world's largest haunted house) in Elkins Park, PA, and the house from The Silence of the Lambs are on the market. Depends on the state  In New York, if the seller has "claimed to the public at large" that the house is haunted, he or she must disclose the spooky status to buyers.   Believe it or not, hauntedness is a legal designation in the real estate industry.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: What's Trending This Halloween
item.description: What other Halloween trends are we watching this year?   You can see what costumes are the most popular by exploring Google's Frightgeist site. Elizabeth Holmes. Another popular fit?

item.description: Last year, sales per store declined nearly 21% annually—a major problem for parent Party City, because Halloween sales account for a fifth of its total U.S. retail revenue. Every year, pop-up Halloween stores rise from the underworld to possess empty storefronts vacated by mortal retailers.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Halloween Candy Sales up 8.6%
item.description: Those mini Crunch bars are big business Shoppers typically spend $4.6 billion on Halloween treats, about 13% of the U.S.' annual candy sales.   As of Oct. 4, Halloween chocolate and candy sales were up 8.6% annually, according to the National Confectioners Association.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: How to Sell a Haunted House
item.description: So how do you sell a haunted house?   That seems to be the exception to rule, because haunted houses are typically not an easy sell. Both Lynnewood Hall (dubbed the world's largest haunted house) in Elkins Park, PA, and the house from The Silence of the Lambs are on the market. Depends on the state  In New York, if the seller has "claimed to the public at large" that the house is haunted, he or she must disclose the spooky status to buyers.   Believe it or not, hauntedness is a legal designation in the real estate industry.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.description: Since then, Halloween has turned into a turkey-leg-at-Disney-World-sized revenue driver for the theme park industry.   And parks from Disney World to Busch Gardens report significant Q4 revenue bumps every year thanks to Halloween celebrations.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Business Insider Buys Controlling Stake in Morning Brew
item.description: Why the Brew was attractive: Morning Brew expects to bring in $20+ million in revenue this year, has been consistently profitable, and has incredibly good-looking newsletter writers.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Pennsylvania in the 2020 Election: The Frackstory
item.description: It's been an economic savior for some parts of the state that were hollowed out by the decline of manufacturing jobs, but some Pennsylvanians are against it on environmental grounds.   Biden is currently favored to win the state, per FiveThirtyEight.   + Miss any of our state-level stories this week? It's a swing state that boasts 20 electoral votes.   President Trump won Pennsylvania in 2016, but by only 44,292 votes...
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Netflix Raises Price for Standard, Premium Subscriptions
item.description: WarnerMedia's HBO Max, which parent company AT&T said has 57 million global subscribers. Netflix is expected to pass 200 million subscribers this year, and those dollars add up.   NBCUniversal's Peacock, which collected nearly 22 million users after three months.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: U.S. GDP Rose 7.4% on Quarterly Basis in Q3
item.description: Overall, GDP is down 3.5% this year.   On a quarter-to-quarter basis, Q3 GDP rose 7.4%, following a 9% drop in Q2. **Annualized rate: measured as if the economy will continue growing at that pace for a full year. But the third wave of Covid infections and the lack of federal stimulus could be a drag on those numbers.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Big Tech Reports Big Tech Earnings
item.description: Apple posted strong numbers for its fiscal Q4 that modestly beat expectations, with Macs and AirPods offsetting weaker iPhone sales.   The context: Apple has worked on shoring up its software and services, plus it’s boosted products like AirPods and the Apple Watch.   Facebook beat expectations on both revenue ($21.5 billion) and daily active users (1.8+ billion, up 12% yearly). After the bell yesterday, four Big Tech bigwigs dispatched earnings reports.   Google parent Alphabet also reported blowout earnings, with profits at $11.2 billion and revenue at $46 billion last quarter.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Big Tech Reports Big Tech Earnings

After the bell yesterday, four Big Tech bigwigs dispatched earnings reports.   Google parent Alphabet also reported blowout earnings, with profits at $11.2 billion and revenue at $46 billion last quarter.

item.title: How to Get Morning Brew Swag for Free
item.description: Here are 6 strategies for racking up referrals and getting free Brew swag just in time for the holidays.   To a copywriter named Rob Allen, the undisputed king of Brew referrals with well over 3,000 to his name, Quora is a nonstop referral generator. That’s because when you hit certain referral milestones, we’ll send you Morning Brew swag, like a mug or even a sweatshirt.   2. Do what this guy did   Giphy  To most people, Quora is just a popular site people visit to ask questions and find answers to every subject under the sun. But using your group chats to sign people up for the Brew can actually be a referral magnet.   You can read Rob’s blog post about his referral conquest here, but the short version goes like this: he identified a commonly asked question about the stock market, answered it intelligently, added his referral link at the bottom of his answer, then watched the referrals pour in as his post earned over 180,000 page views.   6.   5.   4.   1. Let the Brew sell itself. Do what Alex and Austin did   Sara Hillstrom The cofounders of the Brew know a thing or three about getting email signups.   And if you get in trouble...   Once people have taken the bait and interacted with the screenshot (or even if they haven’t), hit them with a follow-up text saying “Btw, if you want to sign up for the Brew, here’s the link.” Here's how:  First, send an initial text to your group, but don’t include your referral link yet.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: The Essentials, Issue #77: Wicked
item.description: Leading Off    Giphy For those of you who love to get spooked, you might’ve heard of the infamous Corpse Husband (aka Corpse).   Happy Place    Ben Hider / Getty Images Between the handwritten book recs and the tucked-away reading nooks, independent bookstores are definitely one of my Happy Places.      R&R   Portland Press Herald / Getty Images Pre-candy-binge appetizer: RIP to my dinner plans.   -------- See you on Monday when I’ll still be snacking on Halloween candy.   In character: Abby Roberts is TikTok’s Halloween makeup guru.   Stay Sharp  Candy craze: Use these ingenious hacks to (safely) distribute candy to all the Mandalorians and Cobra Kais who come knocking on your door.   Mid-candy-binge horror movie: If you’ve already watched The Shining and Carrie, here’s your next hit list of horror movie recs.   Pre-candy-binge workout: Forget your pasta sauce jar weights—what you need is a pumpkin.   Cooking tip: October is also known as spooky shroom season.
item.author: Rachel Cantor

item.title: Founder of Utah-Based Tech Company Qualtrics Buys the Utah Jazz
item.description: In 2018, just before Smith was set to take Qualtrics public at a $5 billion valuation, European software giant SAP offered $8 billion to buy the company, which Smith accepted.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Heathrow no Longer Europe’s Busiest Airport
item.description: Heathrow said it had been overtaken by Charles de Gaulle in Paris as the busiest airport in Europe, with Amsterdam Schiphol and Frankfurt “close behind.”   Passenger testing is important because it allows travelers to avoid long quarantines following a trip.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Trump’s Promises to Wisconsin Manufacturing Workers Disappoint
item.description: In 2018, President Trump visited Wisconsin to break ground on what he called “the eighth wonder of the world,” a high-tech manufacturing facility for TV screens that would bring 13,000 jobs and $10 billion in investment to the swing state.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Google, Facebook, and Twitter CEOs Spar With U.S. Lawmakers over Section 230
item.description: “Congress should update the law to make sure it’s working as intended.”   Here are the best soundbites from the feisty affair: "Section 230 is the Internet’s most important law for free speech and safety.” Big Tech’s version of the Avengers assembled yesterday, when Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, and Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai faced off against a Senate panel over the widespread protections Section 230 offers their tech empires.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Why Europe Locked Down—Again
item.description: The moves made the Continent’s stock markets swoon  The Stoxx 600, a pan-European index, suffered its worst one-day drop since September ahead of Macron’s announcement.   France’s neighbor Germany also enacted a partial, month-long lockdown.   Bottom line: The U.S. and Europe have resoundingly failed to hold onto the progress made over the summer against the virus.   The WHO said the European region accounted for almost half of the new Covid-19 cases reported last week. German restaurants, bars, gyms, concert halls, and theaters will close starting Nov. 2.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: The Perfect Investment Does Not Exist
item.description: Investing in the stock market can feel that way, too.   The market will always ebb and flow, but if you take a long term approach to investing with money you can afford to let sit and grow, the best time to start is still ASAP. Then use your time to stay informed on certain sectors, read up on quarterly earnings reports of big companies, and earmark that cash to invest the next time there’s a market downturn. The idea of perfect timing doesn’t apply to smart investing—leave that to boarding escalators and planning the perfect proposal. It’s human nature to plan for the perfect moment—be it proposing to your partner on a beach with an airplane banner, or landing the perfect step on an escalator at the mall.
item.author: Morning Brew

item.title: Biden, Trump Face Off in FInal Debate
item.description: Zoom out: For the 45+ million Americans who already voted, this debate didn’t change much. Trump said Biden would "destroy the oil industry."   Climate: Biden said his plan would transition to cleaner industries, create millions of jobs, and get the U.S. to zero emissions. T-minus 11 days for everyone else. No pressure.
item.author: Alex Hickey
